Without a clearer understanding of the rate of emission by eruptions or by seepage through cracks in the crust of various gases, including the major constituents carbon dioxide and water vapour, the way in which the hot, high-pressure climate is maintained at present and may have varied over time will also remain obscure. The detailed cloud composition, its
associated chemical cycles, and the causes of the vertical and horizontal variations and their time dependences, are further major unknowns linked to volcanic activity.
While the gross features of the general circulation are now clear, many details of things like the drive mechanisms for the zonal super-rotation, and the morphology and behaviour of the polar vortices, are yet to be understood. A great deal of meteorological activity has been observed, for example wave structure in the ultraviolet markings, huge variations in sulphur dioxide concentrations above the clouds, and dramatic cumuliform structure in the deepest cloud layer, although none of these has been investigated yet in sufficient detail to define the processes at work.
The magnetosphere and near-space environment of Venus are quite different from Earth and again, while the gross features are now known, many features of great complexity and variability remain to be explained. A particular goal is to understand how the solar wind interacts with a non-magnetised planet to remove atmospheric gases over long periods of time. This, and other processes that have shaped the environment on Venus, including the likely loss in the distant past of a large body of water comparable to the terrestrial oceans, require much more data for their elucidation and quantification in climate models.

sections.heading: 7 Future Mission Concepts, and International Collaboration
sections.text:
Addressing the problems outlined above requires a variety of investigative approaches, in particular new and more ambitious space missions (Glaze et al. 2018, this issue). The recent era, which emphasised orbiters and entry probes, is likely to be followed by long-lived landers, eventually with mobility, and buoyant stations in and below the cloud layers. Seismic measurements, which would contributing to addressing important but poorly-understood problems relating to interior structure and composition, are lacking at present, although it has been shown (KISS study 2015) that useful data could be obtained not only with conventional seismometers adapted to the difficult conditions on the surface, but also by balloonborne or even orbiting sensors.
Sample return has been studied in some detail but requires significant technology development and comes at a high price. Nevertheless, the proximity of Venus to Earth, the diversity of exploration craft required, and the obvious relationships to Earth science, make Venus an ideal target for international collaboration, possibly featuring separate elements from different spacefaring nations. India and China have already shown interest in longterm plans, along with the agencies already involved in Venus missions, namely those in Russia, Japan, Europe, and the USA. It is regrettable that so much potential has not resulted in an active programme of missions to follow Venus Express and Akatsuki. Venus has huge, untapped scientific potential to inform our understanding of the evolution of young, rocky planets with atmospheres, including Earth and extra-solar Earthlike planets.

references.title: Induced magnetosphere and its outer boundary at Venus

abstractText: This is a review of current knowledge about Earth’s nearest planetary neighbour and near twin, Venus. Such knowledge has recently been extended by the European Venus Express and the Japanese Akatsuki spacecraft in orbit around the planet; these missions and their achievements are concisely described in the first part of the review, along with a summary of previous Venus observations. The scientific discussions which follow are divided into three main sections: on the surface and interior; the atmosphere and climate; and the thermosphere, exosphere and magnetosphere. These reports are intended to provide an overview for the general reader, and also an introduction to the more detailed topical surveys in the following articles in this issue, where full references to original material may be found.
title: Venus: The Atmosphere, Climate, Surface, Interior and Near-Space Environment of an Earth-Like Planet
